description: From Middle English wrake, wrache, wreche, from a merger of Old English wracu, wrÃ¦c (â€œmisery, sufferingâ€) and Old English wrÇ£Ä‹ (â€œvengeance, revengeâ€). See also wrake.

entries.meaning: (archaic, dialectal or literary) Vengeance; revenge; persecution; punishment; consequence; trouble.

examples: Lytle was already moaning in shame, fallen back in bed with his hand across his face like he'd just washed up somewhere, a piece of wrack.

verbs.description: wrack (third-person singular simple present wracks, present participle wracking, simple past and past participle wracked)

entries.meaning: (UK dialectal, transitive) To execute vengeance; avenge.
(UK dialectal, transitive) To worry; tease; torment.

description: Late Middle English, from Middle Dutch wrak, ultimately related to Proto-Germanic *wrekanÄ… (â€œto drive outâ€), the source of wreak and wreck. Doublet of vraic.

Cognate with German Wrack, Old Norse rek, Danish vrag, Swedish vrak, Old English wrÃ¦c); also compare Gothic ğ…ğ‚ğŒ¹ğŒºğŒ°ğŒ½ (wrikan), ğ…ğ‚ğŒ°ğŒºğŒ¾ğŒ°ğŒ½ (wrakjan, â€œpersecuteâ€), Old Norse reka (â€œdriveâ€).

entries.meaning: (archaic) Remnant from a shipwreck as washed ashore, or the right to claim such items.
Any marine vegetation cast up on shore, especially seaweed of the family Fucaceae.
Weeds, vegetation or rubbish floating on a river or pond.
A high flying cloud; a rack.

verbs.description: wrack (third-person singular simple present wracks, present participle wracking, simple past and past participle wracked or wrackt)

entries.meaning: (transitive, usually passive) To wreck, especially a ship.
Alternative form of rack (â€œto cause to suffer pain, etc.â€)
